Pros: Great company to work for
Cons: Low pay and early first shift

Review Title: Great company, great pay, solid customer base, ample sales opportunities
Pros: Lots of great supportive people who are more customer focused than other tech giants I have worked for. The offer I accepted was higher than I had expected for my experience level (Around $100k base / $100k comm for Enterprise AE role with 10 yrs B2B exp.). Lots of selling tools, a dedicated CSM (vital to your success), a shared SDR, and a shared SME for each major product category. Customers generally like us, are easy to engage with and accept meeting requests. Competitive offerings with lots to upsell within accounts across other departments and LOBs.. The products are competitive and sufficiently suited for customers' needs,
Cons: It can be easy to get stuck in discussions about legacy paper-based services that customers know Iron Mountain for (offsite records storage and doc shredding are their bread and butter). While there is a big opportunity for converting these legacy customers to digital services, Iron Mountain has most room to grow in it's cloud, digitization, and digital storage businesses. Nearly all sales are generated within existing customers who have large offsite storage accounts already, by forming relationships with the right people to find new projects, expansions, and renewal upsells. Frequent account team changes and annual rep reassignments seem to have the most damaging impact to these relationships. Rarely are deals won from a position of clear product superiority or lowest price, but rather from trusted relationships with the customer's AE and account team.

Review Title: The people here are really good, the process is not
Pros: The people on the team are all very good at what they do. They work really well with each other and with outsiders. I could easily ask anyone for help and I can easily give anyone constructive criticism.
Cons: The technology department rules the roost, upper management loves to talk about design first, but they will not back it. Dev will take over and make poor decisions to hit deadlines instead of making a good experience for the users. This has been happening over multiple years and we lose potential clients because of it. We also desperately need a business analysts that can create requirements.

Review Title: Awesome place to learn and grow
Pros: I was recruited to join Iron Mountain a year ago. When first contacted I thought, "the shredding company?" which is a common misperception. Iron Mountain is so much more. Our Matterhorn growth and transformation story is awe-inspiring and to be able to be even one sentence of one page of one chapter of that growth story makes me feel like I'm having an immense impact. Not to mention the Head of Executive Search and the Head of Talent Acquisition are 2 of the best bosses I've had in my 20+ year career. They really know the industry and the talent function, and have the patience to impart what they know in a meaningful and resonant way. I am beyond blessed to have joined such a great team and am delighted to be able to help recruit some of the best and brightest executives to join our climb.
Cons: The organization is growing and changing so rapidly that (1) sometimes it is hard to keep up with what each of the business units are doing which can be challenging when trying to tell the full IRM story and (2) there are internal transitions that are part of the growing pains of an organization undergoing this much transformation.

Pros: Good working hours no weekends
Cons: Bad morale working environment management is terrible

Pros: Teamwork is wonderful! Management goes above and beyond going at bat for the team. My team is fully remote. Work is challanging fast pased and rewarding.
Cons: There are no cons to list yet. Other than teams in Brazil do not make added income for on call rotation as of yet.

Review Title: Great place to work and grow
Pros: Absolutely love the team and the people and culture at Iron Mountain. If you are looking for a great place to work, when people respect each other, they value their team members and appreciate talent. This is the place for you. The senior mgmt clearly communicates throughout the organization, there is a sense of camaraderie and belonging for all employees. It has a diverse group of people from around the world and everyone's opinions matter at Iron Mountain. I feel like you can get heard and everyone is fighting to win customers - working towards presenting our best foot forward. Customer comes first and I love that everyone's always working to make this a better place to work.
Cons: Like all companies there are always things that can be a hinderance in your work like the company is too big and sometimes takes long to get things approved or done, sometimes there are too many people involved or you don't know whom to go to for a resolution in IT. But that comes with any big organization. I also think budgets get shifted, but that is also normal elsewhere. I think working with awesome people overrides all these issues that probably exist in every company. I'd pick great culture over these cons.

Nothing really stands out, the yearly raises aren't even really a benefit due to the tremendously high recent turnover and layoffs.
Cons:
Executives consistently mispresent the truth and hide critical information from employees. In an organizational meeting, one of the executives accidentally said "When are we telling them we are moving" (or along those lines) which prompted a lot of backpedaling and lies until they came clean that they were planning a major move across state and hiding that information until the last minute to prevent workers the ability to look for new jobs. 
Constant layoffs negatively affect the operational efficiency. Employees are consistently overworked and reprimanded. 
The organization ties bonuses to revenue/profit but which is a negative since they will claim a year was not profitable even though they spent 975 million acquiring a company then another 250 million acquiring a second. How is an organization that is spending nearly 1.25 billion acquiring their competition unprofitable and why are bonuses affected by that?

Review Title: American Company with full of Indians
Pros:
$80 commuter credit per month
OK pay package
Cons:
I recently had the experience of working for a company based in Boston, MA, with the Engineering team located in Tampa, FL, and another significant presence in India, encompassing various levels from management to Engineering leads.

During my tenure, I observed some challenges in the organizational culture and communication, which I believe could be improved. Notably, I found the decision-making process regarding layoffs to be unclear. Despite receiving a high performance review (4.0 out of 4.0), I was unexpectedly laid off. This coincided with the company hiring new team members, which raised some questions for me about the criteria used for these decisions.

For those considering employment with this company, I would advise paying close attention to the company culture and communication practices during the interview process. It's crucial to ensure that the environment aligns with your professional values and expectations for a supportive and transparent workplace.

Cons: No office to work in, so you really have to have a good setup at your house. We work globally, so there are occasional meetings before/after normal working hours.

Review Title: Great place to build a career!
Pros: The size and scope of Iron Mountain enables an ambitious employee to advance and pursue new opportunities in various areas. I have been here more than 20 years and had positions in Operations, Account Management, Territory Sales, Digital Solutions and Enterprise Sales. It has been a great career! I can honestly say that any time there have been gray areas, the company made a decision that was fair to me. I appreciate the fact that Iron Mountain did not rest on its reputation as the leader in records management. Instead, leadership recognized that we are an "information" management company. They have developed a wide range of new services and products to keep us relevant as the way information is handled and used changes. The future is bright. I have recommended Iron Mountain to friends and family members and some of them are ow my colleagues here.
Cons: The bureaucracy at Iron Mountain can be frustrating at times. It takes a while to learn how to get things done.

Pros: *Company reputation: we service 95% of Fortune 500 companies. *Flexible work environment: many remote jobs; culture respects family time *Growth mindset: company is constantly working acquisitions and promotes idea generation across all job roles
Cons: *Pay increases and bonuses can be very political/less performance-based: I've encountered 10+ individuals from 3 different divisions offer this or similar unsolicited comment to me, personally, and have countless others say this is the case generally. There is a lot of chatter around annual awards time...frequently encounter these discussions on a yearly basis.

Review Title: Lacked Leadership Diversity. Leadership lacked professional integrity and maturity.
Pros: During interview process, seemed very open to embracing new leader with new perspective, previous experience, expertise and success. There were some senior leaders who respected expertise and welcomed ideas, perspectives and effective leadership skills. Compensation at upper levels is reasonably competitive. Opportunity for cross-functional collaboration if you get "connected" with the right people.
Cons: Certain leaders have privileged attitude and attempt to bully new hires. Lack of professional integrity and maturity among leaders was appalling. Allowing certain leader to go unchecked for their unethical behavior resulted in a very toxic, hostile environment. Taking credit for other's ideas and presenting as their own, sabotaging initiatives, false accusations, inappropriate accusations, falsifications of performance metrics were a constant with certain leaders but not addressed, empowering continued unethical behavior and actions.

They don't care about their employees at all. When I first started there were jobs all over the US and Canada. Year after year jobs went overseas till now there is hardly any jobs except in a center they bought that use to be another companies. I guarantee they will lose their jobs soon enough. CEO only cares about making his millions. He has ruined this company by buying out other companies to gain the monopoly. As an employee they literally work you to death and will keep adding more and more work. Companies including some very large companies are ending contracts because of the fact that they must deal with overseas sweatshops. Stay far away from this company trust me.

He even barred someone from working at the location ever again even though it was stated they are allowed to work there. My advice is to avoid this man. He will ruin your career and not give a damn. Many others in the company are equally as bad so you'll always need to be on guard. There were employees who were sexually harassed by a manager and HR defended that manager. Sad part is, the company is WELL aware the facility is the main place of employment in the area and they take advantage of it.

Pros: Having been at Iron Mountain for over 22 years, I have enjoyed working for this company and value the relationships I have made here. Iron Mountain values their employees/staff. They know that a happy employee is a steadfast employee that will work hard for the company and the brand. I enjoy all the perks being a Mountaineer has provided me and my family. From the great benefits for Healthcare, vision, dental to all the wonderful opportunities for saving on College for my kids, 401K for my future, and many perks to save on auto/home insurance and many, many others.
Cons: The only con that I have to offer is that many positions with the new landscape are now work remotely, and the challenge to that is you are never off or away from your computer/work. Me personally, I don't mind that and it helps me keep up, however that can be a con if you are not use to that, or havent worked remotely before.

Pros: This is an ambitious and innovative company with a vast array of service offerings all over the world which makes it quite unique and interesting to work for. There is always something new to learn, challenge to accept, or problem to solve. It is very inclusive and always trying to expand and evolve.
Cons: With the ambition comes the increase in stress to meet goals for both sales and operations. The organization grew quickly with many acquisitions and currently has challenges with streamlining communication and ensuring all parts of the organization are aligned. Process improvements are underway but I anticipate it will be 2-3 years before this is better for the overall organization.
